(Break at 9:49. Jane said she was very well dissociated this delivery. Her eyes had been open often and her pace had been good. Break had barely begun when she resumed briefly, in a much deeper voice, at 9:50.)(9:49休息。珍说她这一段的出离状态非常好。她的眼睛常常睁开，速度很好。休息还没真的开始，她就以一种更低沉的嗓音在9:50短暂地重新开始。)
One note: Your father felt ineffective and a failure when an automobile did not work right, because of his connection with them, and you picked this up. Which is highly ridiculous, as you can see, since your own interests lie in other directions.有一点：当车子运作得不顺畅的时候，因为他和它们的关联，你父亲觉得自己无能和失败，而你捡起了这个想法。而如你所知，这是非常荒谬的，因为你自己的兴趣是在其他的方向。
(Break again at 9:51 Jane said she realized of course that she enjoyed having a car, any kind of car, available. But she hadn’t particularly associated this with the reasons Seth described to a need for mobility. Nor had she made any great connection with the idea of her father being a traveling man. My idea was that Seth had mentioned these things briefly in much earlier sessions.(再次的，在9:51休息，珍说她当然知道自己享受拥有一台车，任何一种车，有就好。但她没有特别把这点和赛斯说的关于移动需求的这个理由连结在一起。她也没有把这个和她父亲是个旅行者的想法连在一起。我的想法是，赛斯曾在更早之前的课短暂地提过这些。
(Jane now told me that while speaking last time, she received a message from Seth to the effect that from now on she wasn’t to smoke during tests, because of the distraction involved. She didn't have to pause while giving the regular material to get this message, but seemed to receive it on another level simultaneously with the material she gave voice to. She had been smoking so far during the session.(珍现在告诉我，当上一次传述的时候，她从赛斯那里收到一个讯息，从现在起，在测验期间不要抽烟，因为会令人分心。平常在给资料的时候，她并不需要停下来去接收这个讯息，似乎是当她在口述资料的时候，同时在另一个层面上接收到这个讯息。她目前为止在课堂上都会抽烟。
(It was now time for the 30th Dr. Instream test. It did not materialize immediately however, and Jane resumed at 10:01 with her eyes opening occasionally.)(现在开始第30次殷斯翠姆博士测验，不过它并没有立刻开始。珍在10:01重新开始，她的眼睛有时候是睁开的。)
I see that Ruburt received my message correctly. This message was given, incidentally, mentally while he was delivering my words on another subject, and this is an accomplishment indeed.我看到鲁柏很正确的收到了我的讯息。顺道一提，这个讯息是当他在传达我对另一个主题的看法时，同时在精神上接收的，而这确实是一项成就。
We will give Dr. Instream a moment or two while I make a few other remarks.当我再说几点，我们就会开始殷斯翠姆博士测验。
(Jane looked at me now.)(珍现在看着我。)
You are doing very well, much better than you think, generally speaking. Reactions which you would have accepted as natural in the past, you now accept as being unfavorable, as they are. But the recognition, you see, causes you at times to think you are not making progress when indeed you are. You expect more of yourself now, and you are getting more.整体来说，你们做得很好，比你们所认为的要好很多。过去你们会当作是自然而接受的反应，现在会知道那反应的本身是不利的。但这样的认知有时候会让你们认为你们没有进步，但事实上是有的。现在，你期待自己越多，你就会得到越多。
These small episodes of late would have snowed you under in the past, out of all proportion; such is not the case now. You have noticed, I am sure, also, that Ruburt’s reactions are of a more steady nature.这些最近的小插曲在过去会经常的朦骗你；但现在不会了。我很确定你也注意到了，鲁柏的反应有更稳定的本质。
(“Yes. ’’)'(“是的。” )
He does not feel the need to change the furniture with such startling rapidity.他不必觉得有需要在这么短暂的时间里很快的改变。
(“Yes.”)(“好的。”)
Now. Please give us a moment.现在。请等我们一会儿。
(Jane paused at 10:10. She sat quietly with her head down, her hands raised to her closed eyes. She was not smoking. Her pace was now slower, with many brief pauses.)(珍在10:10分停顿。她安静地坐着，低着头，她的手举到闭着的眼睛上。她没有抽烟。她的速度现在慢下来，有着短暂的停顿。)
Something in the nature of a fabric with a wooden framework I believe, for our object. The color blue. The framework is used for support. (40. second pause.) Upholstery. Blue upholstery, with something like small tacks in it that are indented. A blue chair. This is our object. (Pause.)我相信我们的物件是某种布料特质，有着木制框架的东西。颜色是蓝色。框架是用来支撑的。(40秒的停顿)家饰品，蓝色的家饰品，有着参差不齐的小钉子钉在上面。一把蓝色的椅子。这是我们的物件。(停顿)
Disturbing events today, I believe surrounding our Dr. Instream.今天有令人烦恼的事，我相信是在殷斯翠姆博士的周遭。
A snag. Perhaps some difficulty in his hypnosis experiments which had been going so well. For some reason however there seems to be better chances in his ESP card experiments, though not of as spectacular nature as those earlier achieved. (Pause.)一个麻烦。也许是他进展良好的催眠测验遇到了一些困难。不过因为一些原因，他的ESP卡实验似乎有着比较好的机会，虽然没有像之前的结果那么令人惊叹。(停顿)
I believe this change for the better, or this possibility of change, is due to an up spurt on the part of the student, a mood change that can be taken advantage of. There seems to be some connection, to me, at any rate, between the blue chair and this student. (Pause.)我相信这个改变是更好的，或这个改变的可能性，是得力于学生心情的改变。不论如何，对我而言，这里似乎有一些连结，在蓝色的椅子和这个学生之间。(停顿)
Plans that Dr. Instream has been making for a large meeting next spring or early summer will not materialize in the manner that he anticipates. There will be an overall change in them. You may underline overall. (Pause.)殷斯翠姆博士在明年春天或初夏计划举办的大型会议，并不会以他预期的方式实现。这里将会有一个全面性的改变。你可以把全面性划线。(停顿)
A letter from New York mentioning a meeting, the initial P connected with this.一封从纽约来的信提到了一个会议，缩写P与此有关。
I have specifically given the blue chair as object. (Pause at 10:20.) I will ask you, Joseph, for our test, and I will then have a few general remarks to make concerning our tests at this point.我明确地说了物件是蓝色的椅子。(10:20停顿)约瑟，我会问你关于我们测验的事，关于我们的测验这一点我会有一些总体的评论。
(As usual Jane took the sealed double envelope from me without opening her eyes. Her head was tipped down; such was its position that when she held the envelope up, as she has been doing lately, she pressed it against the top of her head. This is the 27th envelope test.)(如往常一样，珍从我手中接过信封，她没有睁开眼睛。她的头低着；就像她最近所做的，握着信封，把信压在头上。这是第27次信封测试。)
Now give us a moment please.现在请等我们一下。
These are impressions.印象是这些。
The habit of squirreling away. A connection with four people, I believe men. A studio. A paper item. (Long pause.)偷藏起来的习惯。和4个人有关联，我想是男人。一间工作室。一件纸的物品。(长时间停顿)
A connection with a photograph that was taken along with others, more than one of its kind in other words.一张照片和其他同时一起拍的照片有关联，换句话说，不是只有这一张。
Now this remark leads Ruburt to think of Lois. Such personal connections are important for our purposes, so I mention them.现在这个论述让鲁柏想到路易(Lois)。这样的个人连结对我们的目的来说是重要的，所以我提到它们。
Now. A square, and a round object, perhaps inside the square. Initials. (Long pause at 10:26.) Ruburt’s connection: a disturbing event. You may put Ruburts connections in parenthesis.现在。一个方形，和一个圆形的物件，也许里面是方形。缩写。(10:26长时间停顿)(鲁柏的关联：一件麻烦事。)你可以把鲁柏的关联这几个字括号。
I pick up a very distant connection with Wisconsin, which I do not understand (pause), and with objects seen from above.我收到一个和威斯康辛(Wisconsin)遥远的关联，(停顿)和上面看到的物件有关。
Also a connection with something like a flag. Horizontal lines and star shapes. Two o’clock.也和某个像旗帜一样的东西有关。水平线和星形。两点钟。
I suggest your break.我建议你们休息。
(Break at 10:29. Jane was dissociated as usual. Her eyes had remained closed. She held the test envelope to the top of her head the whole time. She didn't think she had done well in the test, whereas actually the results were very good.(10:29休息。珍出离如常。她的眼睛仍闭着。她整节课都把信封贴在她的头上。她并不认为这个测验做得很好，但事实上结果非常的好。
(See the tracing of the test object on page 197.(见上面测试物品的素描。
(“The habit of squirreling away" is a good reference to my father, in whose photographic studio my brother Loren took the pictures he refers to in the test letter. The studio is in part of my father's cellar; the rest of the cellar is stuffed and cluttered with odds and ends my father has accumulated over the years. The rest of the family views the overloaded cellar as a fire hazard.(“偷藏起来的习惯”是对我父亲一个很好的注解，在他的照相工作室，我弟弟洛伦照了这张在测验信封里提到的照片。这间工作室占据我父亲地下室的一部分。地下室的其他地方塞满了我父亲累积多年的琐碎物品。其他家人把这间塞满东西的地下室视为火灾危险区。
(“A connection with four people, I believe men.” Three men and one woman were present in the studio when the pictures shown on page 198 were taken, for the correct total of four people: Jane, myself, my father and my brother Loren.(“和4个人有关联，我想是男人。”在拍摄上面的照片时，有3个男人1个女人出现在工作室，正确的总数是4个人：珍、我自己、我父亲和我弟弟洛伦。
(“A studio.” Refers to my father’s photographic studio.(“一间工作室”指的是我父亲的摄影工作室。
(“A paper item.” The test object is a paper item.(“一张纸的物品”测试物件是一个纸的物品。
(“A connection with a photograph that was taken along with others, more than one of its kind in other words.” The test object of course is connected to the photos also indicated on page 198, and these particular photos were connected with “other "s since they were the last two exposures on a roll of film.(“一张照片和其他同时一起拍的照片有关联，换句话说，不是只有这一张。”测验物品当然也和标志在上面的照片有关联，这些相片和“其他的”有关联，因为它们是胶卷的最后两张底片。
(“Now this remark leads Ruburt to think of Lois.” This is a good example of the way personal associations can work. Our friend Lois took some photos of Jane recently, for use on the dust jacket of Jane’s ESP book. The photos my brother Loren took were also to be used in connection with publicity for the ESP book.(“现在这个论述让鲁柏想到路易”。这是一个个人联想运作得很好的例子。我们的朋友路易最近帮珍照了几张相片，用来当珍ESP书的封面。我弟弟洛伦照的照片也是使用在ESP书的宣传上。
(“A square, and a round object, perhaps inside the square.” This is a good reference to the color transparencies my brother took. Again, see the tracings of the photos on page 198. What we have is a rectangular area with rounded corners inside the square object. Perhaps Seth/Jane's perception of the rounded comers led to the statement concerning a round object inside the square.(“一个方形，和一个圆形的物件，也许里面是方形。”这是一个对我弟弟照的彩色幻灯片很好的注释。再次，见上面的照片素描。我们看到的是，在一个四方形的物品里有一个方形区块的圆角。也许赛斯/珍对圆角的感知，导致了有关方形里面有圆形物件这样的结论。
(Initials. The initials “ASA" appear in my brother's letter. There could be other meanings here.(缩写。缩写“ASA”出现在我弟弟的信件里。这里可能有其他的含义。
(“Ruburt’s connection: A disturbing event, ’’ is a good reference to the balance of my brother's letter, which is not included on page 197. The contents of this part of the letter are available however to anyone studying these results.(“和鲁柏的关联：一件麻烦事”是指我弟弟信的内容，这没有写在上面的测验物件里。如果有任何人想要研究结果，这部分信件的内容是可以取得的。
(“I pick up a very distant connection with Wisconsin, which I do not understand”, puzzled Jane, since she had no idea of what this could mean. I thought it might be a reference to the fact that my brother Loren, who wrote the test letter, is a model railroad fan. The magazine Model Railroader was, I thought, published in Wisconsin. There is a strong connection here because Loren has contributed articles and photographs to this magazine for many years. A trip to the newsstand to check verified my idea; Model Railroader has editorial offices in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Jane was especially pleased at this because she knows nothing of the hobby, or the magazine or its address. It took me two days after the session to come up with the connection with Wisconsin myself.(“我收到一个和威斯康辛遥远的关联，但我不明白。”这让珍很困惑，因为她不知道这指的是什么。我想它可能跟一件事有关，写这封测验信件的人，我弟弟洛伦，是个铁路模型迷。我记得这本杂志《铁道模型》是在威斯康辛州出版的。这里有一个很强的连结，因为洛伦这些年来贡献了很多的文章和照片给这本杂志。我还走到书报摊去核实我的想法；《铁道模型》有个编辑办公室在威斯康辛州的密尔瓦基。珍对这点特别满意，因为她完全不知道他的这个嗜好，这个杂志或它的地址。在课后我花了两天才想到和威斯康辛的关联。
(“and with objects seen from above.” This is speculation: Loren's model railroad layout is built at waist-high level in the cellar of his home in Tunkhannock, PA. Thus while standing before it one looks down upon the small models of trains, etc.(“和从上面看到的物件有关”。以下是推测：洛伦的铁道模型是放在他宾州和纳家里的地下室，大概放在腰部高的水平。因此，如果一个人站在前面往下看，会看到火车的小模型。
(“Also a connection with something like a flag.” More speculation: many of the symbols of the various railroads are designed in a flag shape, and Loren has made drawings of some of these symbols for publication, I believe, in Model Railroader.(“也和某个像旗帜一样的东西有关联”。进一步推测：很多不同铁路的象征都是设计在一面旗帜的形状上，我相信洛伦曾画了一些这样的象征在《铁道模型》的刊物上。
(“Horizontal lines and star shapes. " is vague to us, although the test object, the letter, contains horizontal lines of type.(“水平线和星形。”对我们来说很笼统，虽然测验物件，这封信是有水平线的隔线。
(“Two o’clock. " would seem to be a reference to the time the photos were taken of Jane. On a Sunday after a noon dinner at my parent’s home Jane, myself, Loren and my father went down to the photographic studio.(“两点钟”似乎指的是珍被拍照的时间。某一个星期天在我父母家吃过午饭后，珍、我自己、洛伦，和我父亲走进了摄影工作室。
(Jane said that Seth's reference to Lois put her back on the right track as far as subsequent data went. There was a fine distinction to be made here, since both Lois and my brother were involved taking pictures of Jane for the same purpose: Jane's ESP book. Thus Seth and Jane worked very well together here. Also note another example of cooperation, wherein Jane contributed accurately with her connection to a disturbing event, and Seth said this was Janes idea.(珍说赛斯提到路易，让她把紧接着的资料放对了位置。这里有一个细微的区别。因为路易和我弟弟都为了同一个目的帮珍拍照：珍的ESP书。因此赛斯和珍在这里合作得非常好。再写另一个合作的例子，珍对她和麻烦事的连结提供了正确的意见，而赛斯说，这是珍的想法。
(As stated earlier, Jane took the time to relax before the session tonight, and feels it was well worth while.(就如之前所提的，珍花了一点时间在今晚的课前放松了一下，而她感觉很值得。
(Jane's eyes once again opened fairly often when she resumed at 10:40.)(当珍在10:40分重新开始的时候，她的眼睛再次频繁的睁开。)
Now Ruburt may have his cigarette.现在鲁柏可以抽烟了。
He is doing very well. He will automatically improve. I want him to remember this, for there is no reason for him to blame himself when, as in our last test, we did poorly. There is no blame involved.他做得很好。他会自动的进步。我要他记得这一点，比如当我们上一次的测验做得不好时，不要责备自己。这里不涉及责备。
The positive suggestions that he used today were excellent, however. This evening I specifically mentioned the incorrect impression to set him straight. This also represents a fine distinction however on his part.无论如何，他今天的正面暗示用得非常好。今晚我特别提了一个不正确的印象去改正他。不过这也代表了他自己的一个细微的分辨。
We work in our tests almost as one organism, as a gestalt, and you also have a part here Joseph. We were certainly specific with this last test, but there must be freedom first.在做我们测验的时候，我们几乎是以一个整体，就像是一个完形来工作的，而约瑟，你也是这里的一部分。我们对这最后的测验很具体，但首先必须有自由。
Now Ruburt grows unsure as far as Dr. Instream’s tests are concerned, when we are asked for a specific object, and this does hamper us. However this feeling will vanish as we continue, and again, it is a natural reaction on his part so he should not blame himself for it.至于殷斯翠姆博士测验，当我们被要求说出一个明确的物品，鲁柏就越来越没有把握，而这会妨碍我们。不过，当我们继续下去，这种感觉就会消失，而再次的，对他而言这是很自然的反应，所以他不需要责备自己。
We shall end up not only with excellent results on a fairly predictable basis, but your records will form an excellent document that shows how these abilities are used and translated into practical terms.我们不应该只追求可预测性基础下的良好结果，你们的记录会妥善记录下这些能力是如何的使用，以及如何转变为实用的方式。
With many psychics, the ability is so automatic that you can learn nothing about the process as it occurs. Now I shall try to point out impressions that are incorrect when I am able to. You will be able to see how extrasensory perceptions merge with personal associations, and watch the mind as it actually learns to perceive the difference.有许多通灵者，他们的能力是自动地展现出来，所以当过程发生的时候，你无法学到任何东西。现在，当我可以的时候，我应该试着指出不正确的印象。你会看到超感官是如何和个人的联想融合，而看着心智确实的学习感知这些不同。
You will see when and how Ruburts personal associations help us, and when and how they do not help us. As result Ruburt will be able, finally, to screen out the incorrect data. This is difficult simply because the data is legitimate to important layers of the personality, and you can see extrasensory perceptions as they merge with other associations.你将会看到，鲁柏的个人联想何时如何地帮助我们，而何时又如何的帮不到我们。最后鲁柏可以筛检出不正确的资料。这很困难，单纯因为对人格的重要层面，这些资料都是合理的，而你可以看到超感官是如何的和其他联想融合。
(Jane's voice now deepened a good deal and became considerably louder. For more emphasis she rapped on the tabletop. Her eyes were open and very dark.)(珍的声音现在比较低沉，而且变得比较大声。为了强调，她轻敲着桌面。她的眼睛睁开且非常深邃。)
And this is precisely how dreams are formed, and why they appear so often so incomprehensible—for when you examine them you do so in the light of your personal associations only. You view them with only half an eye.而这正是梦形成的方法、和为什么它们常常会显得如此难懂——当你检视它们的时候，你只能从你个人联想的角度。你只用半个眼睛来看它们。
Now, I am fully prepared to speak on. However I am aware that we have approached the time of our usual closing, and you may continue or not, as you prefer.现在，我准备好要继续说了。不过我发觉已经到了我们平常结束的时间，而你可以选择继续或不继续。
(“I’m afraid we’ll have to close then.”)(“那我们恐怕要结束了。”)
You may if you like have a session in which you ask me any personal questions that come to mind. I was holding the material concerning your car for such an occasion, but decided this evening that it was important enough to you to take up a regular session.如果你想要有一节课问我任何关于你心里想的个人问题的话，是可以的。为了这样的场合，我保留着和你们车子有关的资料，但今天晚上平常的课就足够了。
My heartiest good wishes, and I have enjoyed rides in your car.我最衷心的祝福，而我很享受搭你们的便车。
(“That’s good. Good night, Seth. "(“那很好。晚安，赛斯。”
(End at 10:55. Jane was dissociated as usual. Her pace had been good. She said she had been quite aware, this evening, of the presence of another personality in the room with us. She had felt as though she were reacting to a third person, one whom she felt rapport with and hated to see leave. She hadn’t been as plainly aware of the feeling before.(10:55结束。珍出离如常。她的速度很好。她说她今晚相当程度的觉察到，另一个人格出现在房间里。她感觉她对着第三人反应着，一个她觉得亲切而不希望他离开的人。她以前从来没有清楚的觉察到这种感觉。
(Seth’s statements on page 207, to the effect that even incorrect test data is legitimate to important layers of the personality, is probably an important one in our opinion. We have been aware of this possibility and plan to ask more questions about it. I do not recall Seth's referring to this point so plainly before, although he may have. Jane and I do not recall reading anything treating with the subject, and wonder whether it could not be quite a valid field for investigation in itself)(赛斯在上面的声明，即使是不正确的测验资料结果对人格的重要层面也是合理的，我们认为这点可能是重要的。我们觉察到这个可能性，并且计划对此探问更多的问题。我不记得赛斯以前曾如此清楚的指出这一点，虽然他也可能有。珍和我不记得读过任何讨论这个主题的文章，而我们想知道，它本身是否一个可以用来研究的有效领域。)

SESSION 223 第223节 1600年罗与珍及赛斯的丹麦生活


JANUARY 16, 1966 APPROXIMATELY 10 PM SUNDAY UNSCHEDULED1966年1月16日 星期天 大约晚上10点 临时课
(Bill and Peggy Gallagher visited us this evening, and Seth held a rather short unscheduled session. The Gallaghers sat in on the first part of the session. After they left Seth and I had a discussion of moderate length. I made a few brief notes, not verbatim except for the names, which Seth spelled out.(比尔和蓓·加拉格今晚来拜访我们，赛斯举行了一节相当短的临时课。加拉格夫妇在课的第一段有参与。他们离开后，我和赛斯有一个中等长度的讨论。我记下了一些简短的重点，但不是逐字稿，除了赛斯拼出的名字以外。
(After Seth announced his presence Bill said that half an hour previously he had wondered whether Seth might speak. Seth confirmed that at that time he had almost come through, and Jane later told me she had been aware of this, without feeling impelled to have a session.(在赛斯宣告他的出现之后，比尔说半小时前他就很好奇赛斯会不会出现。赛斯说那时候他几乎要透过来了，珍后来告诉我，她也觉察到这点，她并不觉得被迫要举行这节课。
(The exchange was quite jovial among the group. Seth discussed several psychic experiences Bill had noted recently, saying they involved telepathy and precognition. Seth said that as in the case of John Bradley, Bill should become more and more aware of such experiences, now that he is more familiar with these sessions.(我们几个人的交流十分的愉快。赛斯讨论了比尔最近记录的几个心灵经验，说它们和心电感应与预知力有关。赛斯说就像约翰•布莱德利的例子，比尔应该变得越来越能觉察这样的经验，现在他对这些课更加的熟悉。
(Somehow the conversation turned to the lives Jane and I had led in Denmark. When I remarked jokingly that as yet we didn't even know what names we bore in that life, Seth promptly began to spell them out. Jane and I have always been curious about these names.(不知怎地，话题突然转到珍和我在丹麦那一世，我开玩笑地谈及我们还不知道那一世的名字。赛斯马上开始把它们拼出来。珍和我总是对这些名字感到好奇。
(My name in Denmark, in the 1600 's, was Lams Devonsdorf. Seth was Brons Martzens. My wife in that life was Letti Cluse. Jane was my son in that life, his name being Graton. Seth has dealt with our Denmark lives in a few early sessions without going into much detail, and has occasionally referred to them in later sessions. In the second session, while still speaking to us through the personality of Frank Watts, Seth told us he had been a merchant who dealt in spices. He now confirmed that data and gave us a little more information. See Volume 1.(我在1600年代丹麦那一世的名字是拉恩•戴福道夫(Lams Devonsdorf)。赛斯是布雷恩·马提兹(Brons Martzens)。我那一世的太太是那缇•克劳兹(Letti Cluse)。珍那一世是我的儿子，他的名字是昆特(Graton)。赛斯在早前的一些课里曾提过我们在丹麦的那一世，那时并没有讲到很多的细节，在后来的课里，他偶尔有提到它们。在第二节课，当还是透过法兰克•沃兹的人格在和我们说话时，赛斯告诉我们，他曾是一个香料商人。他现在确认了这个资料，并给了我们更多的讯息。见第一册。
(Brotzanin II had been one of the ships with which Seth had been connected in his Denmark life. The II, he told us now, meant that this was the second ship by that name. It had been a Danish frigate—a warship before coming into Seth’s hands as a merchantman. Seth owned it in 163T32, and used it in the spice trade.(布提赞那二世(Brotzanin II)是和赛斯在丹麦那一生里有关联的其中一条船。他现在告诉我们，二世，是代表第二条用这个名字的船。它曾是一艘丹麦的护卫舰——在成为赛斯手上的一条商船前，它是一艘军舰。赛斯在1631至1632年拥有它，它被用来运输香料。
(Bill Gallagher doubted that warships were used by merchantmen but Seth told us this was common in those days; all ships had to be armed anyhow as a protection against piracy. The Brotzanin II had not been in very good shape when Seth acquired her. The conversation led to some of the voyages the ship made. Seth quite emphatically reminded us that most of the time he “kept his feet on dry land, ” but he did talk about a few voyages he made. He stressed that he was a merchant rather than a sailor.(比尔·加拉格对于军舰被用来当商船的事表示怀疑，但赛斯告诉我们，在当时那是很平常的；所有的船为了怕在海上被抢，或多或少都有武装。当赛斯买下布提赞那二世时，它的状况并没有很好。话题来到这艘船的一些航行。赛斯强调说，大部分时间他都“停留在陆地”，但他的确提到少数的几次航行。他强调他是商人，不是水手。
(In talking about his voyages, Seth said that we would have to bear with Ruburt now, because Ruburt—-Jane—knew very little about geography; this I can vouch for. Jane now spoke quite slowly, with her head down and her eyes closed, whereas before her eyes had opened often and her manner had been very animated and cheerful.(谈到他的航行，赛斯说他得忍受鲁柏——珍——对地理的无知；这点我可以保证。珍现在说得很慢，她的头低着，眼睛闭着。她的眼睛频繁地睁开，她以愉快又兴致勃勃的方式说话。
(Seth told us the Brotzanin II had followed a warm current and that her voyage took 22 days to “our first port, where we added some supplies.... We were then 42 days out before another port. You will have to bear with me here.... 62 days then to our destination. Nutmeg from one shore, cloves from another.”(赛斯告诉我们，布提赞那二世跟随着暖洋流，而航程花了22天到了“我们第一个港口，在那里我们补给了一些物品……我们花了42天到另一个港口。这里你们要等我一会儿……62天到我们的目的地。肉豆蔻来自一个海岸，而丁香来自另一个海岸。”
(Bill and I tried to pin down the route of the Brotzanin II, and seemed to get a course that included the Azores as first stop, then around the bottom of Africa at the Cape of Good Hope, up the east coast to Madagascar and Zanzibar. Zanzibar is the source of cloves, I recall from my own reading; Jane said she did not know this. However Seth said the ship did not stop at Zanzibar on all trips.(比尔和我试着确定布提赞那二世的路线，似乎得到一条航线包含了第一站亚速尔群岛，然后绕过非洲南端的好望角，向上到东岸的马达加斯加和桑吉巴。我从我读过的书里回想，桑吉巴是丁香的源产地；珍说她不知道这点。不过赛斯说，船在航行中没有停过桑吉巴。
(“Lemons, ” Seth told us, “we knew about lemons before the English did. We grated lemon skins and drank the juice, and made the skins into a kind of poultice to put on sores. We dried the skins also and kept them in the hold. "Lemons were used in those days as a protection against scurvy.(“柠檬”，赛斯告诉我们，“我们比英国人更早知道柠檬。我们磨碎柠檬皮喝柠檬汁，然后把皮做成一种敷料敷在疮口上。我们也把柠檬皮晒干后保存在瓶子里。”柠檬在当时也用来做为对抗坏血症的保护剂。
(After the Gallaghers left Seth and I continued to talk. Seth told, me I would become a very well-known painter; Ruburt, he said, knew nothing about artists agents or their locations in New York City, he said for the record, adding that there is an agent on 62nd street who can be of great help to me. This is the correct neighborhood, I can attest from past experience. He did not give me the agent’s name. Seth told me I have been working to free my intuitions; I already have enough discipline. With Jane it has been the other way around. Both of us are making good progress. Seth also said that my work would become known partly because of the source of inspiration for some of it—the visions I have that grow out of these sessions.(加拉格夫妇离开后，我继续着这个讨论。赛斯告诉我，我会成为一个非常有名的画家；他说鲁柏不认识艺术经纪人或他们在纽约市的所在地，他补充说有一个在62街的经纪人，他会对我有很大的帮助。我可以从过去的经验证实，这是一个正确的地段。他没有给我那个经纪人的名字。赛斯告诉我，我必须试着释放我的直觉；我太自制了。而对珍来说，刚好是相反。我们两个都有很好的进步。赛斯也说，我的作品会变得有名，有部分是因为一些灵感的源头——我从这些课里所产生的视像。
(Seth said Jane and I should make a trip to New York this spring whether we are asked by anyone or not, meaning Jane's publisher principally. The trip can be of great benefit to us through the contacts we make. These contacts will grow out of our seeing the following people: Don Wollheim, an editor Jane has previously published with; her present publisher; Frederick Fell; Eileen Garrett; and Dick Roberts, a senior editor at Dell Books with whom Jane has published. We should set up appointments to see these people, and should make the trip whether or not publicity for Janes ESP book, to be published this spring, is involved.(赛斯说不管有没有人邀请，这里主要指的是珍的出版商，珍和我今年春天应该去纽约。透过我们互相的接触，这趟旅程会变得很有助益。这些接触来自于我们接下来要见的人：唐恩·韦翰[Don Wollheim]，珍之前出版商的编辑；她现在的编辑，佛德瑞克·费尔[Frederick Fell]；伊林•嘉瑞特[Eileen Garrett]；还有迪克·罗伯茨[Dick Roberts]，戴尔文库[Dell Book]的一位资深编辑，我们应该去约见这些人，我们应该去一趟，不管是为了珍ESP书的宣传，或是今年春天的出版。
(Seth told me that as the years passed and these sessions continued both Jane and I would become more and more sure that he is what he says he is—an energy personality essence. The evidence would pile up.(赛斯告诉我，当几年过去，而这些课持续地进行，珍和我会变得越来越确定他就是他所说的——一个能量人格元素。证据会越来越多。
(In the 221st session Seth suggested we postpone our series of object tests with the Gallaghers. At the same time he described the object the Gallaghers were focusing upon in their home outside of Elmira at session time. Jane learned from Peggy Gallagher later in the week that the object was a miniature teapot. At tonight’s visit I had Bill draw an actual-size version of the teapot for inclusion in the record, and it is found on page 211.(在第221节，赛斯建议我们暂缓和加拉格夫妇一系列的物件测验。同时他描述了在课堂中，加拉格夫妇专注于他们位于埃尔迈拉近郊家中的物品。后来在这周，珍从蓓•加拉格那里得知物件是一个小茶壶。在今晚们来访时，我要求比尔画了一个实际大小版本的茶壶放在记录里，如下图。
(Seth’s data on this test was this: "... we shall give the impression of a rock or stone that can be held in the hand, that has a connection with the water, that is speckled, and gray, with an indentation on it... the word nondescript as applying to the Gallagher object.”(赛斯在这个测验的资料是这样：“……我们的印象是一个可以握在手上的石头或石制的东西，那和水有关，有斑痕，灰色，上面有缺口……毫无特色这个字可以适用于加拉格的物件上。”
(Without indulging in wishful thinking, Jane and I thought we saw some points of similarity in the above data and a miniature teapot, namely the fact that the test object could be held in the hand, had a connection with water, and an indentation. Since this was Janes first such attempt with the Gallaghers, I was curious as to what Seth would say. He now told me that the rock or stone impression was his error, and not Jane’s, or Ruburts.(并不是我们一相情愿的想法，珍和我都认为上面的资料和小茶壶之间的确有一些相似点，事实上这个测验物件可以握在手上，和水有关联，还有缺口。因为这是珍第一次和加拉格夫妇的尝试，我很好奇赛斯会说什么。他现在告诉我，石头或石制东西印象是他的错误，不是珍或是鲁柏的。
(Seth said he was not careful enough in sorting out his own impressions. He picked up accurately enough that the test object could be held in the hand, had a connection with water and an indentation—the opening in the teapot—but erred in the rock or stone terminology, the color and the word nondescript. Bill indicated the color of the teapot in his sketch, saying the object is anything but nondescript. Seth said Ruburt transmitted accurately enough the data he gave. He also said that we would conduct a series of tests with the Gallaghers, involving objects, and that they would be successful.)(赛斯说，他不够仔细的筛出他自己的印象。他正确的收到了测验物件可以握在手上，和水有关联，还有缺口——在茶壶上——但在石头或石制的，颜色和毫无特色这个字眼上犯了错误。比尔在素描里描述了茶壶的颜色，他说这个物件绝对不会毫无特色。赛斯说，鲁柏对他给的资料传送得很正确。他也说我们可以和加拉格夫妇安排一系列的测验，和物件有关，而它们会成功。)
(Reduced-size copies of the identification card used as test object in the 28th envelope test, in the 224th session for January 17,1966.)第224节 现在的行动能改变过去 信封28

SESSION 224 1966年1月17日 星期一 晚上9点 定期课


JANUARY 17, 1966 9 PM MONDAY AS SCHEDULED在1966年1月7日第224节第28次信封测验所用的测验物件，识别卡的缩小版本复本
(See the tracing on page 211. For the test object I used a wallet identification card that I picked up two years ago in an empty house that Jane and I nearly purchased. Both of us had met the owner of the house, Jim Birch, a few times. He had changed jobs and left Elmira at the time we were interested in his house, in June 1964, however. Seth dealt with the purchase of this house in several sessions, saying it would be a good one for us psychically. See these sessions among others: 65, 67, 69, 71, 74, 76, 77, 79, 82. See Volume 2.(见上面的素描。我用的物件是一个皮夹大小的识别卡，这是两年前在一间珍和我差点买下的屋子里捡到的。我们两个见了屋主吉姆•贝区(Jim Birch)几次。在1964年6月，他换了工作，离开了埃尔迈拉，我们当时对他的房子感兴趣。赛斯用了几节课在谈买这间房子的事，说它对我们心理上来说是好的。见以下几节：65、67、69、71、74、76、77、79、82。见第二册。
(The test object was among other papers that we cleaned up at the house, with the intention of mailing them to Mr. Birch's new address in North Carolina; later we learned this wasn’t necessary and the papers lay forgotten in my file until I came across them the other day. As far as I know Jane never did see this specific item among the papers. I sealed it in the usual double envelope after placing it between two pieces of board.(测试物件是夹在我们清理房子的文件之中，我们本来打算把它们寄往贝区先生在北卡罗莱纳的新家；后来我们知道没有这个必要，因此文件就放在档案夹里被遗忘了，直到那天我翻到它们。因为我知道珍从来没有看过这个东西。我把它放进普通信封里封好。
(It will be remembered that these sessions began two years ago through our contacting a personality called Frank Watts, who was superseded by Seth in the fourth session. Jane and I have made a few sporadic attempts to learn more about Frank Watts; such a man did live in Elmira, we learned, through a resident who knew him. Since the sessions we keep an eye out for the name in the local paper, especially in a section called “Twenty Years Ago This Week, ” which is printed every Sunday.(记得两年前这些课刚开始时，我们的接触是透过一个叫法兰克·沃兹的人格，在第4节课他就被赛斯所取代。珍和我曾试过几次想了解关于法兰克·沃兹的更多事；我们从认识他的一个邻居知道，这个人曾住过埃尔迈拉。自从这些课开始，我们就开始留意地方报纸上的名字，特别是每周日有个专栏叫“20年前的这一周”。
(Last Sunday, in the death notices in this section for the week of January 9-15,1946, I noted the name Richard J. Watts. We wondered if Richard Watts bore any connection to Frank, and I made a point of mentioning it just before session time tonight. This technique usually leads Seth to discuss the point in question during the session.(上周日，在1946年1月9日到15日这周的讣闻这一栏。我注意到一个名字叫理查·沃兹。我们想知道理查·沃兹是否和法兰克·沃兹有关联。我今晚在课前还提到它。这个技巧通常会引导赛斯在课程中讨论这个话题。
(The session was held in our large front room. Jane spoke while sitting down. She was smoking, and her eyes began to open and close often. Her pace was good, her voice average.)(这节课在我们前面比较大的房间举行。珍说话时坐着。她在抽烟。她的眼睛频繁地睁开又闭上。她的速度很好，音量适中。)
Good evening.晚安。
(“Good evening, Seth.”)(“晚安，赛斯。”)
Now. I should like to continue our discussion concerning time.现在。我想继续我们对时间的讨论。
I made the statement that action in the present could alter the past, and now we shall set about explaining the statement.我做了一个声明，就是现在的行动可以改变过去，而现在我们应该对此解释一下。
The past exists as a series of electromagnetic connections, held in the physical brain on the one hand, but it also consists of the same sort of realities retained in the nonphysical mind. These electromagnetic connections can be changed. The present exists as a series of electromagnetic connections in both the brain and the mind, and this is the only reality which you are justified in giving to your present.过去以一连串的电磁连结存在着，一方面保存在肉体的头脑里，但同频实相的组成也保存在非肉体的心智中。这些电磁连结可以被改变。现在是以一连串的电磁连结同时存在于头脑和心智中，而这是一个对你的现在唯一合乎情理的实相。
In other words the past and the present are real to the same extent. At times in fact the past can become more real than the present, and in such cases past actions are reacted to in the present. You take it for granted that present action can alter the future, but present actions can also alter the past.换句话说，过去和现在是同样程度的真实。事实上，有时候过去可以变得比现在更真实，在这样的例子，过去的行动在现在被反应着。你理所当然地认为现在的行动可以改变未来，但现在的行动也可以改变过去。
The past is no more objective, no more independent from the perceiver, than is the present. These electromagnetic connections which compose the past were largely made by the individual perceiver, and the perceiver of course is always a participator.过去并不比现在更客观、更独立于感知者之外。这些组成过去的电磁连结主要是由个别感知者所形成的，而感知者当然也永远是参与者。
The connections therefore can be changed at any time, and such changes are far from uncommon. They happen spontaneously on a subconscious basis a good deal of the time. The past was seldom what you remember it to be, for you have already rearranged it from the instant of any given occurrence.因此连接可以在任何时间改变，而这样的改变是很平常的。它们常常会自发性地发生在潜意识的基础上。过去很少是你所记得的样子，你已经从任何一个特定存在的片刻重新安排它了。
There is of course a composite past that is composed of such individual electromagnetic connections, and this composite past is not the same past that once existed, in those terms. The past itself is being continually recreated by every individual, as attitudes and associations change. This is an actual recreation, and not a symbolic one. The child is indeed still within the man, but he is not the child that once was, in those terms. For even the child within the man continually changes, and again I am not speaking of symbolic change.当然有一个合成的过去是由这个人的电磁连结所组成的，而这个合成的过去并不是那个一度存在的、同样的过去。过去本身持续由每一个个人的态度以及联想的改变而重新创造着。这是真实的、而不是象征性的再创造。这个儿童确实仍存在于这个成人里面，2但他不是那个曾经的儿童。即使这个成人里面的儿童也持续地在改变，而再次的，我说的并不是象征性的改变。
Now. Difficulties are caused when such changes in the past do not occur automatically. Such difficulties as severe neurosis are often caused precisely because the individual has not automatically changed his past. Once more, the only reality that can be assigned to the past is that granted to the symbols and associations and memory images that exist electromagnetically both within the physical brain and within the mind.现在。当过去这类改变没有自动发生的时候就会引起一些困难。比如严重的精神官能症，常常都是因为个人没有自动改变他的过去。再次的，那唯一被赋予到过去的实相，是电磁性的存在于身体大脑和心智那被承认的象征、联想和记忆的影像。
But this is the only reality that can be granted to the present. I am speaking now in your terms only, and this point should be clearly understood, for I am simplifying conditions considerably. A change of attitude, a new association, any of innumerable other actions, will automatically set up new electromagnetic connections, and break others. Now part of this we shall explain later, for these changes obviously affect both the future and the past. But the past, again, is continually changed by you, and by every individual. For basically you see, it is not something done and finished with, as is supposed.但这是唯一一个被现在承认的实相。我现在是以你们的话来说，而这一点必须很清楚地被了解，因为我相当大程度的简化了情况。一个态度的改变，一个新的联想，或任何数不清的其他行动，都会自动地建立新的电磁连结，和打破其他的连结。现在关于这些，我们稍会解释，这样的改变明显影响了未来和过去。但再次的，过去是持续地被你和被每一个个人所改变。基本上你知道的，过去并不是所谓某种已经完成或结束的东西。。
And you are more free than you imagine to completely alter many aspects of your own past. If you say that the future is dependent upon the past, therefore, you must also say that the past is dependent upon the future. Once more, the past was never an independent, concrete object existing apart from the perceiving participator; for he made his past, and its only reality exists in the electromagnetic connections within his own organic and psychic structure.你有比你想像中更多的自由，去完全改变你自己过去的很多面向。如果你说未来是依赖着过去，那么你也必须说，过去是依赖着未来。再次的，过去永远不是一个独立的、确实的、有别于感知参与者之外存在的物件；因为他形成他的过去，它唯一的实相存在于他自己器质和心灵结构中的电磁连结里。
(Jane now smiled. Her eyes were wide open and very dark.)(珍现在微笑。她的眼睛睁大着，眼神深邃。)
Every action changes every other action. We return to our ABCs. Therefore every action in the present affects those actions which you call the past. Ripples from a thrown stone go out in all directions.每一个行动会改变另一个行动。让我们回到基本，每一个现在的行动会影响着那些你称之为过去的行动。一颗石头掷下所产生的涟漪会往所有方向散去。
(Another smile.)(再次微笑。)
I am going to go out rather far on the limb right here. Remembering what you now know about the nature of time, you should know that the apparent boundaries between past, present and future are only illusions, caused by the amount of action you can physically perceive. Therefore, it is more than possible to react in the past to an event that has not yet occurred, to be influenced by your own future.我在这里要谈一个非常不寻常的观念。还记得你现在所知道的，有关时间的本质，你应该知道在过去、现在，和未来之间明显的界限只是幻相，这是由你在肉体上能感知的行动量而引起的。因此，在过去对还未发生的事件反应，或被你自己的未来所影响是再可能不过了。
We are not getting involved here in the free will or predestination question, though we have spoken about it, and we shall discuss it thoroughly in connection with time in general. Suffice it to say that it is more than possible for an individual to react in the past to an event in the future which may never occur.我们在这里不涉及自由意志或宿命论的问题，虽然我们谈过这个，但我们应该彻底讨论和时间的关联。我只需要这样说，一个人在过去对一件可能从未发生过的未来事件起反应，是再可能不过了。
This takes us into the problem of probabilities. I do not want to get too complicated. However I should explain the last statement to some degree. I suggest that you take a break, and I shall continue.这让我们进入可能性的难题。我不想搞得太复杂。不过我应该稍微解释一下最后的声明。我建议你们休息，然后我会继续。
(Break at 9:30. Jane had been dissociated as usual for a first delivery. Her eyes had opened frequently, usually to emphasize a point, and they had been very dark. Her pace had been good, her voice average, and she smiled often. She had also smoked a good deal.(9:30休息。珍在第一段出离如常。她的眼睛频繁地睁开，通常是强调一个重点，而且它们非常深邃。她的速度很好，音量适中，而且常常微笑。她也抽了许多烟。
(She resumed in the same manner at 9:41.)(她以同样方式在9:41分重新开始。)
Now. I am sure that you remember the couple that you saw at York Beach.现在。我很确定你们记得在约克海滩看见的夫妇。
(Yes.)(是的。)
I have explained that these were psychic projections, given physical reality and projected subconsciously into the physical world by you and Ruburt. You then reacted to them in present time, at the time, you understand.我解释过，这些是心灵的投射，由你和鲁柏潜意识投射到物质世界的物质实相。然后你在当时对他们起反应，你明白的。
("Yes.”(“是的。”
(See the 9th, 15th, 17th, 69th and 80th sessions. Jane and I saw this couple, who bore remarkable physical resemblances to us, in the dancing room of the Driftwood Hotel, York Beach, Maine, in August 1963. These sessions began in December, 1963. See Volumes I and 2)(见第9、15、17、69和80节。珍和我在1963年8月，缅因州，约克海滩的漂流木旅馆内的舞厅，看见这对夫妇，他们在外表上和我们如此地相似。这些课是在1963年12月开始的。见第一册和第二册。)
Now. This couple also represented a sort of time projection, for quite literally you could have become what they were. This existed in the present as a probability. You perceived this portion of the probable future in that present, reacted to it; and the probable transformation of yourselves into those images did not occur. Because the past, present and future exist simultaneously however, there is no reason why you cannot react to an event whether or not it happens to fall within the small field of reality which you usually observe and participate in.现在。这对夫妇也代表了一种时间的投射，实事上你们很可能变成他们所是的样子。这在现在以一种可能性存在着。你们在当时感知了这部分可能的未来之一，对它起反应；而你们转变成那种形象的可能性并没有发生。因为无论如何，过去、现在和未来是同时存在的，没有理由你不能对一件事起反应，不管这件事是否恰巧落在你通常观察和参与的小范畴实相里。
On a subconscious basis you react to many events that have not yet occurred, as far as your egotistical awareness of them is concerned. Such reactions are carefully screened out, away from conscious awareness, by the ego. The ego finds such occurrences extremely distracting and annoying, and when forced to admit their validity will resort to the most far-fetched rationalizations to explain them.在潜意识的基础上，你对很多还未发生的事起反应，就你自我层面的觉察度而言。这样的反应很小心地被自我从意识的觉察中过滤掉了。自我发现这样的存在十分烦人和令人分心，当被迫去承认它们的有效性时，就要采取最牵强的合理化来解释它们。
Now. The inner self exists in quite a different fashion than that seen by Dunne. For the inner self can indeed perceive events that will occur after physical death. It is not, and never was, imprisoned by ego time. Its perceptions of other times are merely inhibited by the ego. The inner self can perceive events that will occur to itself after physical death, and it also can see events that will occur in which it is not involved.现在。内我是以一种与唐尼所看到的、十分不同的方式存在。内我确实能感知肉体死亡后将会发生的事件。它不会，而且永远也不会被自我的时间所禁锢。它对其他时间的感知只不过是被自我所抑制。内我能感知到肉体死亡后将会在它身上发生的事件，它也能看到它没有涉及的，将会发生的事件。
In all of these instances however there are uncertainties, for probable future events can be foreseen as clearly as events that will more actually occur. No event is destined to occur, and it can be changed, not only before and during, but after its occurrence. Again, I do not speak symbolically, and I am leaving myself open to many strong critical remarks which cannot all be answered in one evening.不过，在所有的这些例子当中都有着不确定性，因为可能的未来事件和事实上更可能会发生的事件，都是一样清楚的被预见。没有一件事是注定会发生的，它可以被改变，不只是在发生之前或发生期间，甚至在它发生之后也可以。再次的，我不是在说象征性的东西，而我对许多强烈的批评意见保持开放性，但那无法在一个晚上被完整的回答。
You have yourself doubtless thought of some, but we shall do our best to make these ideas clear and understandable, and to explain various complications that can be anticipated. There are for example certain limitations set here that must be clearly stated; but within these limitations you will find that events can be changed, and are constantly changed, regardless of the point or the apparent point of their original occurrence.你们自己大概想过一些，但我们应该尽力让这些想法变得清楚易懂，而去解释可以被预期的各种各样复杂性。比方说，在这里的确设有限制，这一点必须先清楚的声明；但在这样的限制里，你将会发现事件可以被改变，而且是一直的被改变，不管是它们真实发生的那个事实或表面的事实。
All of this applies unless for example an individual is taken completely out of the physical time system. A murdered man will not be returned to physical life in the same fashion, whole and intact, as he was before the murder, for example; for he has been taken out of the particular system of action of which we are speaking.所有这些都适用，除非一个人完全被放到了物质时间系统之外。比如，一个被杀的人无法以同样的方式，完好无缺的以他在被杀之前的样子活回来；因为他已经被带离了我们所说的那个行动的特定系统。
He may return to the system however, as you know, through reincarnation. Many changes may occur however in that same point for the murderer who is still within the system.不过，如你所知道的，他可以透过转世的方式回到这个系统。无论如何当杀人凶手仍在这个系统时，很多改变在那同一点都有可能发生。
I suggest your break.我建议你们休息。
(Break at 10:01. Jane was dissociated as usual. Her eyes had been frequently open. She had smoked and her pace had been a little slower, with pauses. She said Seth was going on with this material when he abruptly realized what time it was.(10:01休息。珍出离如常。她的眼睛频繁的睁开。她有抽烟，速度有一点慢，伴随着停顿。她说当赛斯实然了解现在是几点时，他仍继续这个资料。
(It was now time for the 31st Dr. Instream test. As usual Jane sat quietly with her head down and her hands raised to her closed eyes. She used many short pauses, but her pace overall was fairly good. Resume at 10:11.)(现在是时候开始第31次殷斯翠姆博士测验。就如往常一样，珍静静地坐着，她的头低着，手举到她闭起的眼睛上。她有很短暂的停顿，但她的速度整体来说相当好。10:11重新开始。)
Now. Give us a moment.现在。等我们一下。
For our object, a ring. (Pause.) I believe a gold one. That is, a gold band. (Pause.)我们的物件，一枚戒指。(停顿)我想是金色的。那是一个金色的戒指。(停顿)
In connection with the ring, I pick up an impression of a past event, a gathering in good weather, perhaps summertime, of youngish men and women. An outdoor affair is what I am thinking of, and I believe that it was near water (pause), and that there was a connection with boats.和这个戒指的关联，我收到一个印象是一个过去的事件，一个好天气的聚会，也许是夏天，有年轻的男人和女人。我想是一个户外的事件，我相信它靠近水。(停顿)，那和船有关联。
An afternoon affair. Disconnected from the northeast. The water was a river, I believe. At least it seems to have been banked on either side, so I presume it was a river. Buildings about that seem to have a Gothic structure. (Pause.)一个下午的事件。和东北方失联。我想这个水是指河。至少看起来两边都有岸，所以我假设它是一条河。大楼似乎有着哥德式的结构。(停顿)
They do not appear at any rate to be private dwellings, and seem to have a connection with a fairly distant past. An outdoor party then. This could have been in another country, perhaps England, and the ring is somehow connected to this event.不管怎样，它们看起来不像私人住宅，似乎和相当遥远的过去有关联。还有一个户外的派对。这可能是另一个国家，也许是英国，而这枚戒指多少和这件事有关。
I seem to have the impression of the word Avon as being part of the location, or as indicating the location, and perhaps Stratsford. Perhaps the ring came from a shop somewhere about this location, or events began here at this affair which would end up with the giving of the ring. (Long pause.)我似乎有这个印象，雅芳(Avon)这个字是地点的一部分或是指向这个地点，也许是斯特拉斯福(Stratsford)，也许这枚戒指是来自于这个地点附近的一家店铺，或这件事在这里开始。而以给予这枚戒指结束。(长时间停顿)
Some indication that Dr. Instream does not feel up to par this evening, and that a scheduled event did not occur.有一些事显示殷斯翠姆博士今晚并没有准备好，而一个日常行程的事件没有发生。
Do you have a test for me, Joseph?约瑟，你有测验要给我吗？
(“Yes.”(“的是。”
(It was 10:22. I handed Jane the sealed double envelope for our 28th test; she took it without opening her eyes, then for several minutes held it against her forehead. She spoke at a somewhat slower rate than she had in giving the Dr. Instream material.)(现在是10:22。我给珍一个封好的信封作为我们第28次的测验；她闭着眼睛接过去，然后有几分钟把信贴在额头上。她以一种比给殷斯翠姆博士资料时还慢的速度说话。)
Now please give us a moment and we shall see what we can do. These are impressions.现在，请等我们一下，我们看看能做什么。以下是印象。
An initiation of some sort, the beginning of something.某种开始，某种事情的开始。
Cowardly—I do not know to what this word refers. Yellow. A connection with music. Large shapes in the foreground.胆小鬼——我不知道这个词指的是什么。黄色。和音乐有关联。图画前景中很大的形影。
A black and white photo. Expressed concern—this is tentative—over the lateness of an hour.一张黑白照片。表达关心——短暂的——针对晚到了一小时。
An interior. An indication of green colors. Stubbing of the toe.一个内部的。一个绿色的标志，踢到脚趾。
(Now Ruburt’s personal association with this last impression is of your brother Loren and his wife. You may put this in parenthesis.) (Jane now lowered the envelope to her lap.)(现在对最后的这个印象，鲁柏个人联想到你的弟弟洛伦和他的妻子。你可以加上这一句话。)
Flowers, the odor of flowers as if it is summertime. Either this, or a strong flowery perfume.(珍现在把信封放在大腿上。)
Tumult, meaning noise. In parenthesis now for Ruburt’s impression: (the interior of a trailer, and the country.)花，花香仿佛是夏天。或是这个，或是很浓的花香香水味。
I suggest your break.骚动，指噪音。现在括号的是鲁柏的印象：(一台拖车的内部，还有乡下。)
(Break at 10:30. Jane was dissociated as usual. Her eyes had remained closed. Her pace had been fairly good.我建议你们休息。
(Jane said that while giving the Instream material she had a vague mental impression of an outdoor scene, and of a woman in outdated clothing. This reminded her of scenes in old paintings, as by Degas.(10:30休息。珍出离如常。她的眼睛仍闭着，速度相当好。
(As will be noted most of the data in connection with the envelope test cannot be checked by us. I expected this when I picked the object. The idea in choosing it was to simulate a test in which an object chosen by a third party was used; then this third party would interpret the data, leaving Jane and me free, so to speak. I got the idea for this approach from the 24th envelope test in the 219th session. The object was chosen by Lorraine Shafer, and to some extent she helped us interpret the resulting data.(珍说，当给殷斯翠姆博士资料的时候，她有一个户外场景的模糊心理印象，和一个穿着过时的女人。这让她想起一幅画的场景，是窦加[Degas]画的。
(It will be remembered that Jane and Seth noted many valid emotional connections pertaining to the test object in the 219th session. We feel that with practice Jane and Seth will be able to pick such charges up regardless of what individuals they are attached to, or directed at.(有一点必须要注记，大部分和信封测验有关的资料我们都无法核实。当我选了这个物件时，我就预设到了。选它的想法是想要模仿一种测验是由第三方选物件的方式；这么说吧，由这个第三方取代珍和我来解读这个资料。我是在第219节，第24次信封测验时想到这个方法的。当时物件是由洛琳·雪佛所选的，某程度，她帮我们解读这个资料的结果。
(While giving tonight’s test data, Jane said she had a few mental impressions, and that she believed she could vouch for a few items in the test.(记得珍和赛斯在第219节注明，很多有效的情感连结都和测验物件有关。我们感觉透过练习，珍和赛斯可以收到这样的能量，不管是接触或想到这个人。
(“Flowers... as if it is summertime. "she said, referred to the flower garden at the Birch house we considered purchasing in June 1964. We spent several weekends at the house cleaning up, and Jane weeded the flower garden.(当给今晚的测验资料时，珍说她有一些心理印象，她相信她可以证明测验的一些项目。)
(“Tumult, meaning noise.” referred, Jane said, to the traffic noise we became sharply aware of while working about the Birch house. Although situated on a hillside, the traffic noise seemed to roll up at us, and we used this as a reason for not buying the house. Seth said this was rationalization on our parts. See the sessions referred to on page 212.(“花……仿佛是夏天”，她说，是指我们在1964年6月考虑买下贝区房子的花园。我们花了几个周末去打扫这个房子，珍还在花园里拔草。
(“Country. "Jane said she thought the last word of the data referred to the Birch house being located in the country outside Elmira, and not to be “the interior of a trailer. "(“骚动，指噪音。”珍说，这指的是我们在贝区的房子劳动时很快觉察到的噪音。虽然位于山腰，交通噪音似乎朝我们峰拥而来，而这个理由成为我们没有买这间房子的一个原因。赛斯说这是我们的合理化。
(I joked that I thought “A black and white photo.” meant the wallet identification card had been placed next to a photo in the wallet. There is a “Stubbing of the toe.” incident in my brother Lorens family—one of a humorous nature that has become kind of a standing joke.(“乡下。” 珍说，她认为资料的最后一句指的是贝区的房子，它位于埃尔迈拉近郊的乡下，而不是“一台拖车的内部”。
(Jane resumed at an average pace at 10:43.)(我开玩笑说，我认为“黑白照片”指的是，皮夹大小的识别卡常被放在皮夹里照片的旁边。“踢到脚趾”指的是我弟弟洛伦的家人——一个幽默性质的标准玩笑。
I will shortly end our session.(珍在10:43分以一个适中的速度重新开始。)
As a matter of fact, our own test was a fairly good one. Unfortunately you cannot check up on the impressions with the owner of the card, and there is little reason for me to go into the various episodes connected with the card.我很快会结束我们的课。
Some of the points did concern your attachment to the house which at one time was owned by the owner of the card.事实上，我们自己的测验是一个相当好的测验。不幸的是，你无法核对这张卡的主人印象，而我没有理由继续说明和这张卡有关的其他插曲。
Unless you have any questions for me I will end the session.有一些点的确涉及了你对这个房子的依恋，而这个房子一度被这张卡的主人所拥有。
(I now mentioned the Richard Watts death notice of twenty years ago, described in the notes on page 212.)除非你还有任何问题，否则我要结束这一节了。
It was not our Frank Watts. However there was a family connection of a distant nature. They were I believe second or third cousins.(我现在提到20年前的理查·沃兹的讣闻,见本节开头的笔记描述。)
("I guess that’s it then for tonight. ’’)那不是我们的法兰克·沃兹。不过是他的一房远亲。我想是堂兄弟。
My heartiest wishes to you both.(“我今晚也是这样猜。”)
I will make one small comment here. Ruburt’s association with the trailer was caused by the fact that the owner of the card has a male child, who was somewhat unmanageable. And the owners of the trailer, also living in the country, have a child of similar nature.我对你们俩衷心的祝福。
The large objects in the foreground did refer to the rock ledge, or the ledge of rocks in front of the house.我里我要稍微解释一下。鲁柏会联想到拖车，是因为这张卡的主人有一个儿子，他有点难应付。而这个拖车的主人，也住在乡下，也有一个类似这样的孩子。
(I neglected to mention this on page 217. Jane was aware of the connection here.)在前景一个大的物件确实指的是一个石景，或是在房子前面的石景。
The other impressions all referred to situations connected with the owner of the card. The card was carried next to a black and white photograph, incidentally. And now again, good evening. I close our sessions, Joseph, within a convenient hour, for your own benefits. Any time that you wish a longer session for any reason, simply request it; or a shorter session for that matter.(我忘了在前面提到的这个。珍有察觉到这里的连结。)
(“Yes. Good night, Seth.”其他印象指的都是和这张卡的主人有关的情况。顺带一提，这张卡是放在一张黑白照片的旁边。而现在，再次的，晚安。约瑟，为了你们，在一个合适的时间，我要结束这节课了。任何时候，你为了任何原因想延长课，只要要求就行了；同样的，要短一点也可以。
(End at 10:51. Jane was dissociated as usual. Her eyes had remained closed. Her pace had been rather slower than usual. She said Seth had been quite prepared to continue on inverted time.)(“是。晚安，赛斯。”
(Tracing of my dental appointment card, used in the 29th envelope test, in the 225th session for January 19,1966.)(10:51结束。珍出离如常。她的眼睛仍闭着，速度比平常慢。她说赛斯已经准备好要继续谈到倒置时间。)

SESSION 225 第225节 有些系统以可能性的方式来体验时间 信封29


JANUARY 19, 1966 9 PM WEDNESDAY AS SCHEDULED1966年1月19日 星期三 晚上9点 定期课
(For the envelope test tonight I used my appointment card for my visit to the dentist earlier this month. As Jane did last time she visited Dr. Coined in May 1965, I put myself in a trance state as an experiment, and was very comfortable. I also used Janes appointment card of May 5,1965 as the test object for the 15th envelope test in the 199th session. I picked the card for tonights session because I thought it would be loaded with strong emotional charges of a personal nature, whereas the identification card used in the last test belonged to a person almost unknown to Jane and me.我的牙医预约单的素描，用在1966年1月19日第225节第29次的信封测验
(I placed the card between two pieces of card and sealed it in the usual double envelope. To the best of my knowledge Jane had never seen it, since I carried it in my wallet from the time Dr. Coined’s nurse gave it to me.(今晚的信封测验，我用的是这个月初我去看牙医时所用的预约单。就像珍在上次1965年5月去看克劳西医生[Dr.Coined]时一样，我也催眠自己进入出离状态，把这当作一个实验，结果令人感到非常的舒适。我也曾在1965年5月5日，把珍的预约单作为第199节、第15次信封测验的物件。我为今晚的课选了这张单子，是因为我认为它承载了一个个人本质上强烈的情绪电荷，上次测验用的识别卡属于一个珍和我几乎完全不认识的人。
(The session was again held in our front room, and was not interrupted. Jane began speaking while sitting down and with her eyes closed. Her pace was a little slower than usual. Her manner was most amused, and she smiled often. She hadn’t been speaking long before her eyes began to open frequently; they were very dark. She was smoking as the session began.)(我把这张单子夹在两张纸板中间，然后放进信封里封好。就我所知珍从来没有看过它，因为自从克劳西医生的护士把单子给我以后，我就一直放在皮夹里。
Good evening.(这节课再次在我们前面的房间举行，中途没有被打扰。珍开始说话时坐着，眼睛闭着。她的速度比平常慢一点。她觉得很有趣，常常笑。在她开始说话不久，眼睛就频繁地睁开；它们很深邃。当课开始的时候，她正在抽烟。)
("Good evening, Seth. ")晚安。
I have a few rather humorous preliminary remarks to make, concerning(“晚安，赛斯。”)
Ruburts recent reactions.我有一些相当有趣的评论要说，是关于鲁柏最近的反应。
There were several causes for them, and these reactions were triggered by the visit of your friend Mark last evening.反应是因为几个原因，而这些反应是你们的朋友马克，他昨天的拜访所引起的。
(Mark is Bill Macdonnel’s entity name. See Session 68 in Volume 2.)(马克是比尔·麦唐纳存有的名字。见第二册第68节。)
The reactions are beautiful examples. First of all Ruburt was worried, somewhat, concerning your own reactions when you found that you now had a new engagement for Friday evening, after already planning to cancel a previous one, in order to have some free time for yourself, and he felt to blame since he had already made a commitment to Mark—rather unwillingly, by the way. But it will harm him in no way to help Mark in his endeavor.这个反应是个很好的例子。首先当你知道星期五晚上有一个新的约定时，鲁柏有些担心你的反应，尤其是你们为了让自己更有时间，本来已经打算取消前一个约定，但他和马克又订下了一个约定，他觉得有点自责——顺便提一下，他是相当不情愿的。但是帮助马克去努力一下又不会损害到他什么。
Next, he discovered that another gentleman had also been invited, the owner of another gallery, and a man whom Ruburt quite actively dislikes. Following this, reacting rather typically as a woman, he discovered that he did not believe enough good chairs were available.接着，他发现另一个人也被邀请了，是另一个艺廊的主人，而这个人鲁柏相当的不喜欢。伴随着这点，他反应的就像一个典型的女人，他发现他不相信有足够的好椅子可用。
This is highly amusing, for he did not want to have a chair available for the owner of the second gallery. He did not want him in the house. However he felt quite guilty over this, for the man is a Negro, and he feared that his dislike would be taken as discrimination. To prove to himself that this indeed was act the case, he began a nervous, frenzied and altogether desperate attempt to make certain that enough chairs were available.这是很有趣的，因为他根本不想让这第二间艺廊的主人有位子坐。他根本不希望他在这间房子里。不过，他对这一点很有黑恶感，因为这个人是一个黑人，他害怕他的不喜欢是因为种族歧视。为了向自己证明他不是这样，他开始神经质、疯狂、拼命地试图去确定是否有足够的椅子可用。
He was very fond as a child of Edward Briscoe, who was also Negro. Edward was poor and the victim of circumstances. He helped out in Ruburt’s household, therefore Ruburt feels that he should be extremely pleasant and helpful to any Negro, for this other boys sake. And so he felt extremely guilty because he did not welcome the thought of this other Negro into his house.当他儿童时期非常喜欢爱德华·布里斯可(Edward Briscoe)，他也是一个黑人。爱德华很穷，而且是环境下的牺牲者。他帮助鲁柏的家庭，因为这个男孩的缘故，鲁柏觉得他应该要十分乐意地去帮助任何黑人。因此他觉得非常有罪恶感，因为他有不欢迎这个黑人进这间屋子的想法。
(Jane's childhood friend Eddie, died of diabetes in his early thirties.)(珍童年的朋友爱德华，在30岁出头死于糖尿病。)
He was quite correct in assuming as he did that his upset had little to do with a lack of chairs, since he knew perfectly well that a sufficiency was available. Now, for another piece to our puzzle. The mayor is also to be present upon this occasion, and Ruburt thought subconsciously how pleased her friend, Edward Briscoe, would be in his simple way—in the old days—to be present, and how impressed he would be with the mayor.他的假设很正确，他的不安和缺少椅子并没有什么关系，因为他很清楚的知道椅子是够的。现在，拼图的另外一片。市长也会出席这个场合，而鲁柏潜意识想到他的朋友爱德华·布里斯可——在过去——以他单纯的想法，该有多高兴能出席这个场合。
So Edward and this Negro owner of the gallery became entwined in Ruburts mind. He knew that it would be quite an occasion for this young man to visit informally, so to speak, with the mayor, though he would vehemently deny it; and yet Ruburt did not want the man in the house, therefore denying him such a privilege at least in thought.因此爱德华和这个艺廊的主人，这个黑人，就在鲁柏的心理纠缠在一起。可以这么说，他知道这是一个很棒的场合，让这个年轻人可以非正式的拜见市长，虽然他会激烈的否认；但鲁柏又不希望这个人在屋子里，因此至少在思想层面，他拒绝给他这个优惠待遇。
I decided to mention this since he is at the point now—I am speaking of Ruburt—when he will not accept the superficial reasons given by the ego for many reactions, but seeks to discover deeper causes. There was also some other problem here, in that Ruburt feels, as you do, and quite rightly, that Mark is in over his head, psychologically speaking.我决定提起这个，是因为他正处在这个时刻——我说的是鲁柏——他不再接受自我对很多反应所给的肤浅理由，而打算去寻求更深的原因。这里也有一些其他的问题，心理上来说，鲁柏和你都十分正确地感觉到，马克遇上了他无法解决的困难。
Mark, in attempting to help this other young man, may indeed end up helping himself, for it will turn him outward. But the situation also has other dangers. Because of Mark’s background, subconsciously he fears Negroes; and the fear is so great, unfortunately, that it becomes a fascination. He is repelled and fascinated at the same time.马克，在试图帮助另一个年轻人时，最后也可能会帮了自己，这会帮助他外向。但这情况也有其他的危险。因为马克的背景，潜意识里，他很害怕黑人；不幸的是，这个害怕是如此的巨大，以至于它变成了一种吸引力。他同时感到恐惧又着迷。
I will not take too much of our session up with these matters. Suffice it to say however that Marks interest in this state art exhibit can be of great benefit to him. We shall turn to other matters. You may as you wish include the early part of the session in your records, or exclude it as you wish.我不会在我们的课花太多时间来谈这些事。只是说明，不论如何马克对这个州立艺术展览的兴趣会对他很有帮助。我们应该把注意力转到其他的问题。你可以按你希望的，把这节课一开始的部分放在你的记录里，或是不放也可以。
Let us get back to time. Now. The idea is current in academic psychological circles that the child exists psychologically intact in the man, that the man contains within him the psychological replica of the child that was.让我们回到时间这个议题。现在，这个想法在心理学的学术圈很流行，这个儿童在心理上完整地存在这个成人里，也就是说，这个成人内在包含了这个儿童当时的心理模型。
Such is not exactly the case. The child exists within the man, yes, but he is not the same child. The memories that he thinks are the child’s memories are not memories of a particular event that happened to the child. That is, they do not contain a precise picture of any particular incident that occurred. Each incident is recreated when the memory of it arises, but the memory is changed with each recreation, and subtly changed.这并不全然是事实。这个儿童存在这个成人里，这是对的，但他不是同样的儿童。他记忆里认为是这个儿童的记忆，并不是发生在那儿童身上特定事件的记忆。这是说，它们没有涵盖任何特定事件发生时的那个正确印象。当那个记忆升起的时候，每一个事件都被再创造，但随着每一次的再创造，记忆会改变，微妙的改变。
The past is, then, continually changed. The electromagnetic connections themselves, that make up any particular event—these connections, even while seemingly intact, have changed. The energy that composes them is not the same, and the past is constantly altered. Nothing can stand still, including the past, and any such appearance of stability is an illusion.因此，过去是持续地在改变。组成任何特定事件的电磁连结本身——这些连结，即使看起来似乎原封不动，也是在改变。组成它们的能量并不相同，而过去是持续的在改变。没有任何东西会静止不动，包括过去，而任何看起来稳定不动的迹象都是幻相。
It is as much an illusion to believe that the past has vanished, as it is to believe that the future does not exist. The past does not vanish, for there was no past to vanish, in those terms.相信过去已经消失，或相信未来并不存在，这二者同样都是幻相。过去没有消失，这么说吧，没有过去是消失的。
I suggest your break.我建议你们休息。
(Break at 9:34. Jane was dissociated as usual for a first delivery. Her eyes had opened frequently and her pace had remained a bit slow.(9:34休息。珍在第一段出离如常。她的眼睛频繁地睁开，速度有点慢。
(She said that although she had a good idea of the reasons for her upset this afternoon, she didn’t make conscious connections with her childhood friend, Eddie Briscoe.(她说，虽然今天下午她的不安有许多理由，但她并未有意识地连结到她童年的朋友爱德华·布里斯可。
(Jane resumed in the same manner at 9:44.)(珍以相同的方式在9:44重新开始。)
If you two are finished with your little discussion I shall continue.如果你们两个的小讨论结束，我就要继续了。
I would prefer when possible, and without putting too much of a strain upon you both, that you discuss fairly neutral situations in our breaks, and avoid discussions with such emotional overtones.如果有可能，并且不会造成你们太多压力的话，在休息的时候，你们最好以中立的立场来讨论，而避免带有这类情绪的暗示。
Now. The child does not stay in a neat psychological package, enclosed in the past and insulated from the present or the future. It is not as simple as all that.现在。这个儿童并不停留在一个井然有序的心理包裹中，封闭在过去而孤立于现在和未来之外。它并不是那么的简单。
There is no point where the child ceases and the man begins, and no point where the young man ceases and the old man begins. These are states happening simultaneously, but perceived in slow motion within your system. Not only are they perceived in slow motion, but they are perceived along one line of focus only. The focus is indeed intense, but so limited in scope that it is relatively impossible for you to keep your attention upon the self except in the most inconsistent and fleeting of ways.并没有从哪一点起，儿童结束而成人开始，也没有从哪一点起，年轻人结束而老人开始。这些是同时发生的状态，但在你们的系统里，以一种慢动作被感知着。他们并不只以慢动作被感知，还只以一条线性的焦点被感知。这个焦点的确很强烈，但范围是如此的局限，以至于除非以一种最无常和一闪即逝的方式，否则你们不太可能保持注意力在自己身上。
You no longer perceive the past, therefore you think that it has vanished, and the self that you were has gone. But that particular moment, any particular moment, that you think of as the past, existed before your egotistical perception of it, and is constantly being changed by you, even when you no longer consciously perceive it.你不再感知到过去，因此你认为他已经消失了，而那个过去的自己也消失了。但那个特定的瞬间，那个你想到的，那个你以为是过去的任何一个特定的瞬间，在你的自我感知到它之前本就存在，而且是持续地被你所改变，即使你不再有意识地感知到它。
For the inner self can perceive it, and does change it. The idea of inverted time states that time flows in all directions, and that as each action affects every other action, so time constantly affects itself and continually reacts within itself. The past moment is never completed. Consciously you have simply lost sight of it, and have not followed it through in its endless depths.内我能感知它，和确实地改变它。倒置时间的概念说明了时间往所有的方向流动，而每一个行动影响了另一个行动，所以时间持续的影响它自己，也持续地对它自己反应。过去的瞬间从未完成。意识上你单纯的就是没看见它，没有随着它进入那无止境的深度。
Some systems experience time exclusively in terms of probabilities, in which the self experiences a particular moment most thoroughly, where continuity is achieved not through a continuity of moments but a continuity of self, as it experiences all the various events that exist as probabilities for it in any given instant.有一些系统专门就可能性的方面来经验时间，借此，自我彻底的去经验一个特定的片刻。而连续性被达成并不是透过一种片刻的连续，而是一种自己的连续，它经验了任何特定的片刻内、所有存在于可能性里的不同事件。
You merely skip along the surface, and this is all right. But do not regard this hopping from moment to moment, as from stone to stone, as the approximation of time as it actually exists. The nature of perceptions determines the experience of time.你只是跳过了这个表面，而这是没问题的。但不要认为这种从片刻到片刻的跳跃，就像从石头到石头之间，是时间真正存在的近似值。感知的本质决定了如何经验时刻。
I suggest your break.我建议你们休息。
(Break at 10:01. Jane was dissociated as usual. Her eyes were often open and very dark, and her pace was quite rapid as break approached.(10:01休息。珍出离如常。她的眼睛经常睁开且非常深邃，接近休息时，她的速度变得十分快。
(It was now time for the 32nd Dr. Instream test. As usual Jane sat quietly with her hands raised to her closed eyes. Her pace became quite slow, broken by many pauses of 15. 30 seconds. She had been smoking earlier in the session but did not do so now. Resume at 10:10.)(现在是时候开始第32次殷斯翠姆博士测验。就如往常一样，珍静静地坐着，手举到她闭着的眼睛上。她的速度变得十分慢，被很多15至30秒的停顿打断。她在课一开始时有抽烟，但现在没有。10:10重新开始。)
Now. Give us a moment for our Instream material. (Pause.)现在。为了殷斯翠姆博士的资料，给我们一点时间。(停顿)
A box shape for our object. Small, with something like a transparent top, cellophane or plastic, of that nature. (Pause.) A filling inside, or lining, as of velvet or silk or some such (pause of at least one minute), and perhaps a divider within the box.我们的物件是一个盒子的形状。很小，有某种透明的表面，玻璃纸或塑胶那样的质地。(停顿)里面有填充物，或是衬里，像丝绒或丝绸或之类的东西(至少一分钟的停顿)，也许在盒子里有一个分隔板。
Longer than a ring box. It does not seem to have a cardboard cover, nor to be made of cardboard. Perhaps it holds a pen and pencil. I have the impression of a date, 1936 or 7. Perhaps this is when he obtained the box or its contents, I believe as a gift. Somehow connected with achievement, however. (Pause.)比放戒指的盒子长。它似乎没有一个硬纸板的盖子，也不是硬纸板所制成。也许是用来装笔或铅笔的。我有关于日期的印象，是1936或1937。也许这是他得到这个例子或它的内容物的日期，我相信是个礼物。不论如何，以某种方式和成就有关。(停顿)
A connection with a man as close to him as a brother, so to speak, with sandy hair, who is somehow connected with the object. (Pause of 50 seconds.) The object also had to do with an understanding that was reached between the owner and another man.和一个与他亲如兄弟的人有关联，似乎，有着浅棕色的头发。这个人以某种方式和这个物件有关联。(停顿50秒)这个物件也和拥有者及另一个男人之间所达成的某种协议有关。
Do you have a test for me?你有测验要给我吗？
(“Yes.”(“有的。”
(As usual Jane took the envelope, our 29th, from me without opening her eyes. It was 10:30. She sat quietly, holding the envelope pressed to her forehead. Her pace became somewhat faster.)(珍没有睁开眼睛，如往常一样从我手中接过信封，这是我们第29次的测验。现在是10:30分。她静静地坐着，把信封压在前额。她的速度变得有点快。)
Give us a moment, please. These are impressions.请等我们一下，以下是印象。
Madison Avenue. A trip. A letter or note. (Ruburt thinks of Frederick Fell, in parenthesis.)麦迪逊大道(Madison Avenue)。一躺旅行。一封信或短笺。(鲁柏想到佛德瑞克∙费尔，加括号。)
A disturbing event in the month of June, 64. A connection with another car, not your own. The number 12.I do not know whether this refers to 12 people or not.一件烦恼的事，在1964年6月。和另一辆车有关，不是你们的车。数字12。我不知道12指的是否人数。
A round object. A letter connected with an older individual.一个圆形物件。一封和一个年长的人有关的信。
A symbol. The object connected with an event that happened in the afternoon. The vicinity of another city, and also a connection with an accomplishment.一个象征。物件和一件发生在下午的事有关联。另一个城市附近，也和一项成就有关。
A long narrow road. A filling station.一条狭长的路。一个加油站。
I suggest your break.我建议你们休息。
(Break at 10:27. Jane was dissociated as usual. Her eyes had remained closed. She had no special thoughts about the evenings test data except to say that none of the impressions she heard herself giving made any sense to her.(10:27休息。珍出离如常。她的眼睛仍闭着。她对今晚的测验资料没什么特别的想法，除了说没有任何一个她听到的印象对她是有意义的。
(See the tracing on page 219. Seth goes over much of tonight’s test data, but in order to avoid mixing my notes with his I'll give the usual interpretations Jane and I made first.(见上面的素描。赛斯仔细浏览过今晚的很多资料，但为了避免把我的注记和他的混在一起。我会先写珍和我的解读。
("Madison Avenue. A trip. A letter or note. [Ruburt thinks of Frederick Fell, in parenthesis.]" We agreed this data probably referred to Janes publisher in New York City.(“麦迪逊大道。一躺旅行。一封信或短笺。[鲁柏想到佛德瑞克∙费尔，加括号]”我们同意这个资料可能是指珍在纽约市的出版商。
(“A disturbing event in the month of June, '64. "Jane said she thought this referred to an episode when she should have visited the dentist, Dr. Colucci, but did not. She keeps a brief daily record of activities, and verified her idea. In her notebook she found a record that on May 31,1964, she woke up with a swollen lower left jaw. I thought it a bad tooth. At this time, not having practiced self hypnosis consciously, Jane had a great fear of dentists. Instead of seeing a dentist she visited our doctor next door; he put her on a series of antibiotics that lasted for four days, on into the month of June 1964. The pendulum told Jane the swelling was psychosomatic and not a tooth; the doctor agreed, eventually, and Seth did too, in the 59th session for June 3,1964. See Volume 2.(“一件烦恼的事，在1964年6月。”珍说，她认为这是指当时她应该去看牙医，克劳西医生，但她后来没去。她有简短的记录每日活动，她去核对她的想法。在她的笔记本上，发现一个记录，在1964年5月31日，她醒来时左下颌肿了。我认为是蛀牙。那时，我们还没有开始练习有意识的自我催眠，珍很怕看牙医。她没去看牙医，而是去看了我们隔壁的医生；他给了她持续4天的抗生素治疗，直到1964年6月。摆钟告诉珍，这个肿胀是由心理压力引起的，而不是蛀牙；最后医生同意了这个观点。而赛斯也这么说，在1964年6月3日第59节。见第二册。
(“A connection with another car, not your own.” When I visited Dr. Colucci on January 11 he told me that about a week previously, probably on Sunday, January he had been unable to make the climb up the icy road leading to his home outside Elmira. Dr. Colucci lives on top of a long steep hill, yet this was the first time in three years, he said, that he had been unable to drive home. Jane said Seth gave this bit of test data because we ourselves had had trouble making a nearby steep hill in our own car, also this month. Seth dealt with our own car troubles in the 222nd session. Jane said she thought the association between these two episodes was legitimate.(“和另一辆车有关，不是你们的车。”当我1月11日拜访克劳西医生时，他告诉我大概一周前，可能是1966年1月2日星期日。他的车没办法在结冰的路上爬坡，因此无法回到他在埃尔麦拉郊外的家。克劳西医生住在一个又长又陡的山顶上，但他说，这是3年来的第一次，他无法开回家。珍说，赛斯给了这些测验资料，是因为我们自己的车也在爬附近陡坡的时候出了问题，也在这个月。赛斯在第222节处理了我们车的问题。珍说她认为两段插曲之间的关联是合理的。
(“The number 12. I do not know whether this refers to 12 people or not.” Jane said she believed the “12” came from the address of Dr. Colucci’s office, 12 Walnut Street, around the corner from our address on W. Water Street, and that Seth speculated about people because of Dr. Colucci's waiting room being a gathering place for people.(“数字12。我不知道12指的是否是人数。”珍说她认为“12”是来自克劳西医生办公室的住处，瓦特街112号，就在我们瓦特街住址的转角，而赛斯有关人数的猜测，是因为克劳西医生的候诊室是个聚集人群的地方。
(“A round object. "I thought this referred to the large round light over the dental chair, but it could also refer to many other things.(“一个圆形物件。”我认为这指的是牙医椅上面大型的圆形探照灯，但它也可以指很多其他的东西。
(“A letter connected with an older individual. "Jane said this referred to her letter of January 13 to Dr. Instream. In it she told Dr. Instream of my using the trance state on my visit to Dr. Colucci.(“一封信与一个年长的人有关。”珍说，这指的是1月13日她写给殷斯翠姆博士的信。在信中她告诉殷斯翠姆博士，我去看克劳西医生时运用了出离状态。
("A symbol.” Here again there could be many references.(“一个象征。”再次的，这里可能有很多关联。
(“The object connected with an event that happened in the afternoon. "My dental appointment as shown on the test object was for 2:30 PM.(“物件和一件发生在下午的事有关联。”我的牙医预约单上注明的时间是下午2:30。
(“The vicinity of another city”, was a reference, Jane said, to the fact that Dr. Colucci lives in Pine City. Pine City is one of those small suburban communities that border more populated places like Elmira; though their population is small they actually cover many more square miles of land.(“另一个城市附近”，珍说这是一个参考，克劳西医生住在佩城。佩城是一个环境绕着人口比较稠密的地区比如埃尔迈拉的一个郊区；虽然他们的人口很少，实际上却涵盖了较大面积的土地。
(“and also a connection with an accomplishment.” Jane and I agreed this meant my using the trance state successfully on my visit to Dr. Colucci.(“也和一项成就有关。”珍和我都同意，这指的是我去看克劳西医生时，成功的运用了出离状态。
(“A long narrow road. " We thought there could be association here also in the manner of the previous data about a connection with another car, not our own. Dr. Colucci, as stated, lives atop a hill climbed by a long narrow road. So do the Gallaghers, in the same general area. Dr. Colucci had trouble climbing the road to his home, and we had trouble climbing the road to the Gallagher home.(“一条狭长的路”我们认为，这和之前的资料“和另一辆车有关，不是你们的”是相关联的。如之前所说，克劳西医生住在一个需要爬一段狭长的路才能上去的山顶。在同样的区域，加拉格夫妇的家也是一样。克劳西医生爬坡回家的时候出了点问题，我们爬坡到加拉格夫妇家时也出了问题。
(“A filling station.” We thought there might be a connection here in that our car ran out of gas on the road to the Gallaghers; even so, this data would be too far removed from the test object.(“一个加油站。”我们认为这可能和我们的车在开去加拉格夫妇家的路上没油了这件事有关联；虽然，这个资料和这个测验物件有点遥远。
(Jane resumed, her eyes opening and closing, at 10:50.)(珍在10:50分重新开始，她的眼睛睁开又闭上。)
Now. We will shortly end our session.现在。我们很快会结束我们的课。
The June event did refer to Ruburt’s swollen gums, which were very painful. He feared most strongly that he would have to visit Colucci, and went to the doctor rather than see the dentist—although Colucci was out in the yard, and Ruburt saw him, as he will now remember.这个6月事件，的确指的是鲁柏肿胀的牙龈，那是很痛的。他最害怕的是必须去看克劳西牙医，所以后来宁愿去看医生也不要去看牙医——虽然克劳西医生当时就在院子外面，而鲁柏看到他了，现在他才想起来。
(As soon as the session ended Jane said she did indeed remember seeing Dr. Colucci as soon as Seth mentioned that she would. Dr. Colucci’s office is but four doors down the street from the M.D. she visited. Seth was quite amused in giving this information.)(这节课一结束，珍说，当赛斯提到她看到了克劳西医生后，她确实记起了曾经看到过他。克劳西医生的诊所就在她看M医生的那条街再往下走4个门。赛斯觉得十分好玩的给了这个讯息。)
The gas station association, while not particularly helpful for your purposes, was in some ways legitimate. The other car did refer to the dentist’s difficulty in making the hill, as he told you at your visit. The gasoline station was Ruburts personal association derived from this, subconsciously.加油站的联想，也许对你们的目标没有特别的帮助，但在某些方面是合理的。另一辆车的确指的是当你拜访牙医时，他告诉你的那辆有困难爬坡的车。加油站是鲁柏源自于此的个人联想，潜意识的。
For lately you could not make a hill, and as a result later you went to a gasoline station for gas. This was too broad an association for your purposes, but legitimate, and it should give you some idea of how these things work. For often quite legitimate associations such as these must be bypassed for more specific data. Nevertheless this particular impression does show the evidence of clairvoyant data.因为最近你们也无法开上山，结果是你们到加油站加油。对你的目标物来说是蛮广泛的联想，却是合理的，而它应该给你一些这些事情是如何运作的想法。通常为了更特定的资料，像这些十分合理的联想都必须先绕过。不过这个特定的印象的确是预知资料的证明。
The number 12 did refer to the address. However it was confused with people because of the people in the waiting room. There was a merging here, or a scrambling, of valid information.数字12的确指的是地址。不过因为候诊室里等待的人，所以它和人数搞混了。这里有一个对有效讯息的合并，或混淆。
(“What about the reference to the vicinity of another city?”)(“另一个城市在附近指的是什么？”)
That did indeed refer to Pine City, and connected, you see, the office incident of your appointment with the car incident, which occurred in the vicinity of Pine Citv.那的确指的是佩城，你们看，这是相关的，你预约看诊时发生的插曲和车子无法爬坡的这个插曲，都发生在佩城附近。
The note referred to the appointment card. This led Ruburt to think of Fell however, and a trip.笔记里提过预约单。这让鲁柏想到费尔，和一段旅行。
(Jane and I hesitated to say that the note referred to the appointment card, since Madison Avenue and a trip were mentioned in close approximation, as well as Fell.(珍和我没有说笔记提到预约单，因为麦迪逊大道和一段旅行，还有费尔在最近的课已经提过了。
(“What about the interpretation for the round object?")(“圆形物件的解释是什么？”)
The round object referred to the light. This is my fault. I should have been more specific.圆形物件指的是灯。那是我的错。我应该更具体一点。
(“And the letter to an older individual?”)(“而给一个年长的人的信”呢？)
The letter to the older individual referred to Ruburts writing to Dr. Instream about your trance, induced during your Colucci appointment.给年长的人的那封信指的是鲁柏写给殷斯翠姆博士的，有关你看克劳西医生时运用出离状态的信。
(“The symbol?”)(“象征？”)
The symbol was a distortion referring to the round object.这个象征是一个扭曲，指的是圆形物件。
I saw at first the object as if it were—the round object which was the light—as if it were on the card.我首先看到的物件仿佛它在——圆形物件是灯——仿佛它就在单子上。
(Jane and I think this a most interesting bit of information. We also compare it with the number 12 data, wherein the numerals in the dentist’s address became scrambled with the idea of people in his waiting room. Only now, it appears, is Seth beginning to get this specific in his interpretation of test data.)(珍和我认为这是最有趣的讯息。我们也把这和数字12的资料做比较，在这里，牙医地址的号码和他候诊室的人数搅混了。只有现在，赛斯似乎开始把他对测验资料的解释说得更具体一点。)
Madison Avenue simply means New York City to Ruburt, and was connected to his Fell associations, which were wrong.麦迪逊大道对鲁柏来说意味着纽约市，而这和他对费尔的联想有关联，但这是错的。
Now, they were wrong, but there was a connection here, in that Mr. Fell had recently had throat difficulties. Ruburt picked up the connection with the mouth, you see.现在，它们是错误的，但这里是有关联的，费尔先生最近喉咙不舒服。你看，鲁柏收到和嘴巴的关联。
(Jane’s publisher had written her recently that he had had throat trouble.)(珍的出版商最近写信告诉她，他喉咙不舒服。)
As always I could continue. However we shall gracefully dismiss ourselves. My heartiest wishes to you both.就如往常一样，我可以继续。不过我们应该优雅的解散。我对你们俩最衷心的祝福。
(“Good night, Seth.”(“晚安，赛斯。”
(End at 11:05. Jane was dissociated as usual. Her pace had been average, her eyes had opened frequently. As usual, she said, Seth could have continued indefinitely.)(11:05结束。珍出离如常。她的速度适中，眼睛频繁的睁开。如往常一样，她说，赛斯可以无止尽继续下去。)

SESSION 226 第226节 可能性事件 约翰


JANUARY 24, 1966 9 PM MONDAY AS SCHEDULED1966年1月24日 星期一 晚上9点 定期课
(Friday evening, January 21, Jane had some success hypnotizing both Bill and Peggy Gallagher at their request, separately. The experiment was not planned. Peggy has been hypnotized twice—one of these times by Dr. Milton Erickson—but this was Bill’s first experience. Dr. Erickson is nationally known.(1月21日星期五晚上，珍在比尔和蓓·加拉格的要求下，成功地分别催眠了他们。这不是计划中的实验。蓓曾被催眠两次——一次是被米尔顿·艾瑞克森[Milton Erickson]医生——但这是比尔的第一次经验。艾瑞克森医生是国际知名的医生。
(Jane achieved partial success with Bill on two attempts. The first try was the best. Bill was unable to open his eyes and developed good amnesia in his left hand, these being the tests Jane used to show him something about the trance state. However he was not able to speak during either session, and came out of the state both times when Jane asked him to answer questions. He did succeed in relaxing very well. This is difficult for him to do; he has ulcers.(珍在两次催眠比尔的尝试中获得了部分的成功。第一次的尝试最好。比尔无法睁开他的眼睛，而且左手完全麻木，珍试着透过这个小测验显示给他看，什么是出离状态。不过不管在哪一节课里，他都无法说话，而当珍要求他回答问题的时候，两次他都离开了出离状态。他的确很成功的放松了。这对他来说是很难做到的；他有溃疡。
(Nor was Peggy able to speak during her first session and left the state when Jane began to ask her questions. On the second attempt Jane succeeded quite well by using a more authoritative approach. She did not ask Peggy questions this time. Peggy attained a deep enough state to show no reaction when Jane placed our cat, Willy, on her stomach as she lay on the divan. Peggy has a deep fear of animals in general and cats in particular, this being why Seth calls her the cat lover.(蓓在第一节时也无法说话，而且当珍开始问她问题的时候，她就离开了出离状态。在第二次尝试的时候。珍用了比较权威的方法，因此相当成功。她这一次没有问蓓问题。蓓达到了一个很深的状态，以至于当她躺在睡榻上，珍把我们的猫，威立，放在她的肚子上时，她都没有反应。蓓对动物有很深的恐惧，特别是对猫，这也是为什么赛斯叫她爱猫人士。
(All of us, including Peggy, were amused when she insisted that she tolerated Willy’s presence because she thought Jane was touching her, instead of the cat.(我们所有人，包括蓓，都觉得很好笑，她坚持说，她容忍威立的存在是因为，她以为是珍在触摸她而不是那只猫。)
(Seth came through briefly shortly before the Gallaghers left, at about I AM. He told us he had watched the proceedings with much pleasure and amusement. He explained that Bill had allowed the hypnosis to proceed just so far before his ego called a halt, but that he could progress. Seth said Peggy used rationalization in saying that she stood for Willy’s proximity because she thought Jane touched her instead of the cat. Peggy, Seth said in high good humor, had actually achieved an excellent state of deep hypnosis when Jane used the more authoritative approach; otherwise she wouldn’t have permitted the cat’s presence.(在加拉格夫妇离开前，大约深夜一点，赛斯短暂的透了过来。他告诉我们，他带着十分愉悦和好玩的心情看着这个过程。他解释比尔允许催眠进行到他的自我叫停之前，但他是可以更进步的。赛斯说，蓓认为是珍在触摸他而不是那只猫，这是一种合理化。赛斯以很幽默的方式说，当珍用更权威的方式后，蓓确实达到了一个很深度的催眠；否则她不会允许猫的存在。
(I was somewhat dubious about Jane's hypnosis attempts since we haven't had time to do much work in this direction lately. But Jane said she felt like it, and the Gallaghers insisted that she try. I didn’t think Bill could be easily hypnotized, but he was quite pleased with his results for a first attempt. Both Bill and Peggy said they thought they could have done better had Jane taken more time with her induction, yet Jane's approach had been quite leisurely; thus time appeared to have been compressed for them.(我对珍的催眠尝试有些不确定。我不认为比尔是容易被催眠的人，但他对第一次尝试的结果十分满意。比尔和蓓都认为，如果珍多花一点时间在她的诱导上，他们可以做得更好，珍的方式是十分悠闲的；虽然时间显得很紧张。
(Seth had the interesting comment to make that he had looked out at us from Jane's eyes during the evening, along with Jane, and that he saw us as individuals instead of composite electromagnetic images embodying our pasts, presents, and futures. On two very brief occasions Seth let his voice blast out to some extent, though not at full volume by any means. The hour was late and I was quite aware of possible reactions from neighbors in the house.(赛斯有个有趣的评论，他今晚从珍的眼睛看着我们，和珍一起，他看到的我们是以个人的样子，而非合成的，包含了我们过去、现在、未来的电磁形象。在两个很短的时刻，赛斯的音量突然提高，虽然并不是很大声。但时间已经晚了，我小心的觉察附近邻居可能会有的反应。
(No envelope test was held during tonight’s session.(今晚的课没有信封测验。
(The session was witnessed by John Bradley, our friend from Williamsport, PA, who attends a session occasionally. John usually inspires Seth in a telepathic/clairvoyant way, and so tonight some effects were obtained also. The last session John witnessed was the 204th.(我们来自宾夕法尼亚州，威廉波特的朋友约翰·布莱德利参与了这节课，他偶尔会来上课。约翰常以心电感应/预知的方式带给赛斯灵感，而今晚也有这样的效果。上一节约翰参与的课是第204节。
(When he first appeared John mentioned that he had attended a meeting for medical salesman in Cleveland OH earlier this month; John is a sales representative for Searle Drug. As soon as he mentioned Cleveland I asked him to say nothing more about it, in the event Seth chose to do so later. Fortunately Jane was out of the room at the moment and did not hear Cleveland mentioned.(当他出现的时候，约翰提到他这个月参加了俄亥俄州克里夫兰的医药销售员会议；约翰是塞尔药厂的业务员。当他一提到克里夫兰的时候，我就要求他不要再说更多，也许赛斯等一下会说这件事。很幸运的，珍那时不在房间，没有听到他提过克里夫兰。
(The session was held in our large front room, in full light as usual. Jane began speaking while sitting down and with her eyes closed. As is often the case when witnesses are present she seemed to draw upon extra energy; her pace was fast from the start, and her voice stronger and somewhat deeper than usual.)(这节课是在我们前面较大的房间举行的，如往常一样灯光全亮。珍开始口述时坐着，眼睛闭着。当有参与者在场的时候，她似乎能汲取更多额外的能量；她的速度从一开始就比较长，声音比平常大声且低沉。)
Good evening.晚安。
(“Good evening, Seth.”(“晚安，赛斯。”
([John:] “Good evening, Seth.”)([约翰：]“晚安，赛斯”)
My welcome to our friend Philip.我诚挚欢迎我们的朋友菲利普。
Now. If our exuberant Ruburt has calmed down, and if our friend Philip has put down his paper, we shall begin.现在。如果我们精力充沛的鲁柏可以冷静下来，还有我们的菲利普可以放下他的报纸，我们就应该可以开始了。
(Jane had been very pleased with some humorous poetry she had written today, and had been reading it to John before the session. John’s entity name is Philip. Just as the session began he had been folding a newspaper; as usual Seth wasn’t bashful about asking for quiet.)(珍对她自己今天写的幽默诗句很满意，在上课前，她还读给约翰听。约翰存有的名字是菲利普。课一开始的时候，他正把报纸折起来；如往常一样，赛斯毫不客气的要求我们安静。)
I would like to give you some more material this evening concerning our inverted time system, for when you understand how it operates then you can begin to take advantage of it more readily.我今晚想要给你们多一点有关倒置时间系统的资料，如果你们知道它是怎么运作的，那么就可以开始更迅速地从中得利。
I will leave it to you, Joseph, to cut me short if I speak too quickly.约瑟，如果我说得太快，你可以打断我。
